e4: The new policy discloses accurate financial information, which reduces potential reputational risk and investor misunderstanding. However, this change disadvantage some retail investors who are less sophisticated and would have traded at an advantage against more informed hedge funds by ignoring biases like the $0.50 EP bias under old reporting policy.
e5: A reporting policy is considered ethical when it provides accurate and unbiased financial information to stakeholders. This entails a high degree of transparency, with reported numbers being true reflections of a company's actual performance. Any adjustments or qualifications must be clearly explained, providing investors with the necessary context to make informed decisions. Furthermore, an ethically sound policy ensures non-discrimination and fair treatment among investors, irrespective of their sophistication level, without compromising the integrity of financial reporting.
e6: As a board member considering changing to a new reporting policy, I would have several follow-up questions. Questions might include: Can more sophisticated investors easily identify and ignore the bias, without impacting retail investors significantly? Are there mechanisms in place or plans being considered to address information discrepancies among less-investor types once new policy goes into places?
